awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  An Integrative Field and Biophysical Model of Thermal Stress, Physiological Performance, and Reproductive Fitness
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals experience thermal stress at the extremes of their geographic range. This stress may be compounded by climate change, especially when the geographic range stretches over a large range of latitude. Many species use behavioral thermoregulation to ameliorate heat stress.  However, these compensatory behaviors have a cost, as they require the animal to abandon critical behaviors that may only be performed in the hot and stressful habitat. This study investigates these survival/reproductive tradeoffs in fiddler crabs, small semi-terrestrial crabs that occupy shorelines in the tropics and temperate zones. Male fiddler crabs use visual displays to attract mates in the hot, dry intertidal zone, but must periodically retreat to a cool, moist burrow to rehydrate and recover. Each retreat to a burrow requires a cessation of mating behavior. Periodically the males rereat from the hot reproductive areas to rehydrate and feed. This study will determine the tradeoff between thermoregulation and mating performance across a species' geographic range, using both experimental and modeling approaches, under both current and predicted future conditions. Finally, the project will utilize the results of the research on fiddler crabs to increase public interest in science using public outreach activities and the training students at different levels including high school students. 

Behavioral compensation for thermal stress can lead to a profound but under-investigated tradeoff, as thermoregulatory behaviors are costly. Energetic and thermoregulation costs will generate major reproductive opportunity costs, which can reduce mating success. This project focuses on the fitness consequences of missed mating opportunities associated with thermoregulatory behaviors. These missed opportunities are crucial to understand in the study of mating success in the context of physiological stress and the differences in costs at different latitudes. Understanding the associated reductions in fitness are crucial to fully understand and predict the consequences of climate change on fitness, since heating in lower latitudes may truncate the benefit of mating owing to the increased cost of thermal stress. This proposal takes an integrative approach, combining laboratory measurements, manipulative field experiments, and biophysical modeling to examine the fitness consequences of behavioral thermoregulation. This work, and the resulting model, will be broadly applicable to the study of climate change impacts on ectotherms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project integrated diverse measures and approaches to develop a quantitative model of behavioral choice, time, and energy investment in the context of thermal stress and climate change, using fiddler crabs as a model system. Fiddler crabs represent a unique model system due to their abundance, varied distributions, and complex mating system. Male fiddler crabs retreat from the sediment surface into burrows to reduce thermal stress, at the cost of cessation of courtship and this potential missed mating opportunities. These missed opportunities are crucial to understand in the study of mating success in the context of physiological stress and understanding the associated reductions in fitness are crucial to fully understand and predict the consequences of climate change on fitness. Our work focused on the Atlantic sand fiddler crab, Leptuca pugilator, which has a geographic range extending from the Florida Panhandle, around the Florida peninsula and up the Atlantic coast to Cape Cod. We combined (a) laboratory experiments on thermal tolerance, thermal sensitivity, and behavioral thresholds, (b) observational field work to examine activity patterns across the range of the species, (c) manipulative field experiments examining impacts of abiotic conditions and social context (e.g., competition, availability of potential mates) on behavior and mating opportunities, and (d) biophysical modeling to examine the fitness consequences of varying thermal regimes, including impacts of behavioral thermoregulation. 

Thermal conditions experienced by this species differ across the range of the species, yet during the peak mating season (summer), male fiddler crabs experience thermally stressful conditions as they perform the courtship display on the intertidal sediment surface. While on the surface, body temperatures very quickly exceed preferred and optimal body temperatures, and water is lost at a rapid rate, forcing frequent retreats to the burrow. Once an individual enters the burrow, body temperatures decrease rapidly and water is absorbed from the moist sediment. Although male crabs active on the surface in the high intertidal mating area are subject to high temperatures and rapidly lose water, it does not appear that experiencing desiccation stress, as all crabs were near full hydration. This suggests that these crabs are capable of managing desiccation stress through frequent returns to the burrow to rehydrate. Interestingly, laboratory experiments also indicate that fiddler crabs are able to alter the permeability of their exoskeleton and thus have some physiological control over water loss rates, which may facilitate enhanced evaporative cooling under certain conditions. Our results indicate that as temperatures increase, the time available for surface activity and thus courtship, decreases. Yet it is not abiotic conditions alone that determine when a fiddler crab retreats to the burrow and later emerges back onto the sediment surface. Instead, these behavioral decisions are also influenced by the social context, including the perceived likelihood of mating and the presence and behavior of other males (competitors), which influences the relative costs and benefits of continued courtship in the face of thermal stress vs. cessation of courtship for a retreat to the burrow. In comparing thermal performance curves and thermal sensitivity of various performance metrics among populations, we observed that individuals from the southernmost population (e.g., the trailing edge population in the context of climate-driven range shifts) were superior to the higher latitude populations over a broad range of temperatures, but especially at the higher temperature examined. These results indicate that this southern population are not likely to be as vulnerable to impacts of continued warming in the near-term as might be expected. Yet this southern population also exhibited the most limited acclimation ability when compared to the more northern populations. 

 

Our results shed light on the complex nature of physiological and behavioral impacts of thermal stress on ectotherms, including the interplay between abiotic and social cues driving behavior across the range of a species with a wide latitudinal range. Our laboratory and field results were integrated into a complex biophysical model that not only can be used to examine future changes in thermal stress but also resulting modifications in activity patterns and mating opportunities. These results provide insight into the behavioral and physiological responses of intertidal and semi-terrestrial ectotherms to climate change, and a framework for integrative studies examining not only the potential for range shifts, but behavioral and reproductive outcomes as well. The results of this study are broadly applicable to the study of climate change impacts on ectotherms.

This project has resulted in four peer-reviewed publications to date, with 5 additional manuscripts in preparation for submission. Additionally, this project resulted in over 12 presentations at regional, national, and international scientific meetings. Beyond the scientific outcomes, this study also resulted in an educational exhibit in The University of Southern Mississippi Marine Education Center’s exhibit hall and multiple presentations in public lecture series. This project trained one postdoctoral researcher, three graduate students, and three undergraduate interns.
